title: Quiz 2: Adolescent Development & Life Skills
topicName: Unit One: Introduction to Reproductive Health
description: Evaluate your knowledge on adolescent biological changes, psychological needs, and essential life planning skills.

questions.question: What is the approximate age range for 'Adolescence' as generally shared by both sexes?
questions.explanation: While onset varies, the two sexes share an approximate range marking adolescence from 13 - 18 years.
questions.hint: It corresponds roughly to the teenage years.

questions.question: Match the hormone with its specific effect on secondary sexual characteristics:
questions.explanation: Oestrogen drives female secondary characteristics; Androgens drive male secondary characteristics.
questions.hint: One is the primary female hormone, the other male.

questions.question: Which of the following are psychological/emotional characteristics of adolescence? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Decreased interest in the opposite sex

questions.explanation: Adolescents typically seek independence, value peer opinions highly, experience mood swings, and have increased interest in the opposite sex.

questions.question: The first ejaculation in boys is technically known as ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Spermache refers to the first ejaculation, often occurring as nocturnal emissions (wet dreams).
questions.hint: It sounds similar to 'menarche' but for sperm.

questions.question: Based on the text provided, what is the prevalence of HIV among female adolescents aged 15-19 in Kenya?

richContent.content:
Statistics:
  • 20% of adolescents sexually active by 14
  • HIV prevalence (Females 15-19): 22.3%
  • HIV prevalence (Males 15-19): 4.2%

questions.explanation: HIV prevalence among female adolescents (15-19) stands at 22.3%, significantly higher than males (4.2%).
questions.hint: Look closely at the data in the box.

questions.question: Which life skill is defined as 'being confident and able to make a stand on one's words, actions or beliefs', such as saying NO to drugs?
questions.explanation: Assertiveness includes the ability to say NO to drugs or sexual advances based on one's beliefs without being aggressive.

questions.question: Research confirms that providing sex education to young people leads to earlier and increased sexual activity.
questions.explanation: Studies have shown that sex education leads to safer behavior and does NOT encourage earlier or increased sexual activity.
questions.hint: Does knowledge generally lead to recklessness or responsibility?

questions.question: Which of the following principles should be applied when working with young people? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Refer to providers of the same sex where possible

questions.explanation: Young people have specific needs: they require privacy, confidentiality, and often respond better to peers or same-sex providers.
questions.hint: Consider what makes a teenager comfortable seeking help.

questions.question: Order the following steps in a logical decision-making process for an adolescent facing a dilemma:

items.text: Make the decision and take responsibility

questions.explanation: Problem ID -> Info gathering -> Weighing options -> Action/Responsibility.
questions.hint: You can't weigh choices before knowing the facts.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a right of assertiveness?

options.text: Right to refuse requests without guilt

questions.explanation: Assertiveness involves standing up for oneself WITHOUT violating the rights of others or intimidating them.
questions.hint: Assertiveness is positive; aggression is negative.
